column1: I just moved back into my apartment after a year abroad. There are three of us total
column2: each with our own room and a shared kitchen/bath/hallway. I probably should mention I’m neurodivergent (ADHD). My schedule isn’t “typical
column3: ” and nights are when my brain finally clicks into focus. During the day I’m slammed with classes/work/errands
column4: and I’m still unpacking and getting my life reset after being away for a year.

column2: the shared areas were cluttered and dusty and my boxes ended up in the hallway while I figured out where things go. I’ve been working on putting felt pads on furniture
column3: reorganizing cabinets so we all have space
column6: cleaning. I value a clean shared space because we all use it.

column1: One of my roommates is a very light sleeper who goes to bed earlier than me (he calls anything from 11pm–1am “early” for him
column2: but sometimes he turns in even before that). He’s told us before that noise at night bothers him. We try to be respectful
column3: but he also expects the apartment to be near-silent for his entire sleep window
column4: which can stretch to eight or nine hours. In a shared place with three adults on different schedules

column1: The other night around 22:45 I was finishing rearranging in the hallway and wanted to vacuum up the mess—dust
column3: and the grit that had collected under a shelf I moved. It was a small area and I figured I could knock it out quickly so no one was stepping on dirt for days. I closed doors to muffle sound and planned to keep it brief. He came out immediately and “confronted” me (his word later) saying it wasn’t okay to vacuum that late because he wanted to sleep and it might bother the neighbors. I said I’d try to be quieter
column4: but I did need to finish because it was my only window that day and the cleaning benefits all of us. I also pointed out that his interest in sleeping is valid
column5: but so is everyone else’s interest in being able to use the shared spaces and maintain them.

column1: We went back and forth. I offered to finish that pass and switch to silent tasks after
column2: or schedule the rest for the first window I had the next day. He basically wanted me to stop immediately and not do anything “noisy” at night at all. He frames it as “late
column3: ” but we never agreed on house quiet hours
column4: and he chose to live with two night owls. He often labels normal living sounds—dishes
column6: a quick vacuum—as “being noisy.” He also throws in “the neighbors” as a reason

column1: I ultimately stopped as a favor
column2: but he left me feeling like cleaning and setting up my space was somehow wrong. Since then I’ve tried to front-load louder tasks when I can
column4: and use the soft vacuum head. But the reality is some nights are my only window to do apartment maintenance or finish assembling furniture. I don’t wake him to ask permission to exist in shared areas; I just try to be considerate and efficient.

column1: Why I think he’s at fault here:
- He’s unilaterally imposing his sleep schedule on common spaces without a house agreement
column2: expecting near-total silence for long stretches every night.

column1: - He hasn’t pursued reasonable mitigations for his sensitivity (white noise
column4: moving his bed away from the hall
column6: and instead defaults to restricting everyone else.

column1: - He waited until the moment I was cleaning to lay down “rules” rather than setting up a house meeting to agree on quiet hours and chore windows.

column2: time-limited tasks that benefit all of us (vacuuming after rearranging
column3: clearing hall clutter) as personal attacks
column4: and uses hypothetical neighbor complaints to shut things down.

column1: - He chose roommates with different hours and then refuses to compromise beyond “don’t do it when I’m sleeping
column2: ” which with his schedule is often the only time I can focus.

column1: I’m happy to agree on concrete quiet hours and a cleaning/chore schedule we all sign off on
column2: and I’ve already made changes to reduce noise. But making shared spaces beholden to one person’s bedtime—without offering workable alternatives—isn’t fair.
